item.title: Global Health: U.S. Becomes More Vulnerable to Tropical Diseases Like Zika
item.description: A changing climate and human factors are sending viruses like Zika toward the United States.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Q&A: How Do Sunni and Shia Islam Differ?
item.description: With Saudi Arabia’s execution of a Shiite cleric inflaming tensions in the Middle East, here is a primer on the differences between the two branches of Islam.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HARNEY
item.media:description: Sunnis and Shiites praying together on Sunday in Beirut, Lebanon, in protest of the execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr.

item.title: Sweden and Denmark Add Border Checks to Stem Flow of Migrants
item.description: The moves by the two Scandinavian countries represented another step in the erosion of the ideal of borderless travel across most of the European Union.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Security staff checked identifications at Kastrup train station outside Copenhagen on Monday.

item.title: Disappearance of 5 Tied to Publisher Prompts Broader Worries in Hong Kong
item.description: The events have alarmed many who fear the historic agreement guaranteeing the former British colony its separate government and legal system may have been dealt a blow.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Notices for Gui Minhai, left, one of five men tied to the Mighty Current publishing house who have disappeared, and Yiu Mantin, a publisher in Hong Kong who was jailed for what friends and family say were plans to release a politically delicate book.

item.title: Indian Forces Kill 5th Gunman in Battle at Pathankot Air Base
item.description: The fighting stretched into a third day at the base near the Indian-Pakistan border, which was infiltrated Saturday by at least six attackers described as a “well-trained suicidal squad.”
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: 3 Sunni-Led States Join Saudi Arabia’s Diplomatic Feud Against Iran
item.description: Bahrain, Sudan and the United Arab Emirates severed or downgraded ties in the dispute, which could set back efforts to broker peace in Syria.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: A demonstration in Tehran on Monday against Saudi Arabia, after the kingdom cut ties with Iran.

item.title: Letter From America: An America Conflicted About Outsiders
item.description: Last year, the United States was roiled by hostility toward immigrants. Yet stories about the insight of outsiders also emerged in literature and on the big screen.
item.dc:creator: ANAND GIRIDHARADAS
item.media:description: The speaker of the House, Paul D. Ryan, at a news conference on Capitol Hill in November. Mr. Ryan was among the representatives calling for restricting the resettlement of Syrian refugees in the United States.

item.title: U.N. Rights Monitor for Palestinian Territories Resigns
item.description: Makarim Wibisono cited Israel’s refusal to grant him access to the West Bank and Gaza as he stepped down from the United Nations Human Rights Council.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Earthquake Strikes Northeast India, Killing at Least 6
item.description: The quake, of magnitude 6.7, left scores wounded, and the death toll was expected to rise.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Soldiers inspecting a house in Imphal, the capital of Manipur State, which collapsed after an earthquake struck northeast India.

item.title: 3 Held in Killing of New Mayor in Mexico
item.description: The fatal shooting of Gisela Mota, who was sworn into office less than a day before she died, increased concerns about organized crime in the area.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Hocine Aït-Ahmed, a Pro-Democracy Algerian Leader, Dies at 89
item.description: After freedom from France, Mr. Aït-Ahmed remained an influential figure in Algerian politics, pushing for democracy and opposing successive governments.
item.dc:creator: AMIR JALAL ZERDOUMI
item.media:description: Mr. Aït-Ahmed speaking at a rally of his Socialist Forces Front, the nation’s first opposition party, in Algiers in 1999.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Cuts Ties With Iran Amid Fallout From Cleric’s Execution
item.description: Saudi Arabia gave Iranian diplomats 48 hours to leave the kingdom as the two powers exchanged heated words after the Saudis executed a prominent Shiite cleric.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Bahraini women carried pictures of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, the Saudi Shiite cleric executed by Saudi Arabia, during a protest near the capital, Manama, on Sunday.

item.title: New Elections Likely in Catalonia After Separatist Leader Is Rebuffed
item.description: In a vote by a far-left party’s political committee, the leader of the region, Artur Mas, failed to gain the necessary support to remain in office.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Sergi Saladié, left, Gabriela Serra, center, and Xevi Generó, members of the Catalan party known as CUP, in Barcelona on Sunday.

item.title: Haifa Journal: In Israeli City of Haifa, a Liberal Arab Culture Blossoms
item.description: The embrace of secularism, feminism and gay rights in the cafes and bars of this cosmopolitan city is creating a counterpoint to Israeli Arabs’ traditional conservatism.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kabareet bar in Haifa, Israel. “We want a gay couple to go to the dance floor and kiss each other, and nobody to even look at them,” said Ayed Fadel, who runs the bar. “This is the new Palestinian society we are aiming for.”

item.title: Sinosphere: Bringing U.S. Presidential Debates to a Chinese Audience
item.description: The Guojiang Subtitle Group brings together about 70 volunteers from across the country to produce Chinese subtitles, including for the presidential debates.
item.dc:creator: OWEN GUO
item.media:description: Republican presidential candidates debating in Las Vegas on Dec. 15. A network of volunteer translators in China called the Guojiang Subtitle Group has been posting videos of the debates online with Chinese subtitles.

item.title: Hunt for Gunmen Continues at Air Base Near India-Pakistan Border
item.description: Nearly a dozen people have been killed in fighting between armed gunmen and Indian security forces at the base near India’s border with Pakistan. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack yet.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Indian officers checked employees of the Pathankot Air Force Base in Punjab on Sunday. Nearly a dozen people have been killed, including four attackers, in the fighting.

item.title: On Perilous Migrant Trail, Women Often Become Prey to Sexual Abuse
item.description: Along with all the perils refugees face, women have added accounts of being assaulted, traumas that do not end with their arrival in Europe.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Djamila Grossman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 35-year-old Syrian refugee, Samar, in November with her three daughters, then 2, 8 and 13, at a shelter in Berlin. “Everybody knows there are two ways of paying the smugglers,” she said. “With money or with your body.” Samar refused a smuggler's advances in Turkey, and was threatened.

item.title: 2 Israelis Charged in Deadly Attack on Palestinian Family in West Bank
item.description: Amiram Ben-Uliel was charged with murder, and a minor who was not named was charged with conspiracy in the arson attack, which killed a Palestinian toddler and his parents.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: A Palestinian inspecting the house in the West Bank village of Duma that was burned in an arson attack in July. A toddler was killed in the blaze, and his parents later died from their injuries.

item.title: Uber’s No-Holds-Barred Expansion Strategy Fizzles in Germany
item.description: The ride-hailing company has retreated from several German cities. Its withdrawal from Frankfurt offers a case study of what went wrong.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Benjamin Kilb for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hasan Kurt, the owner of a local licensed taxi business in Frankfurt, refused to work with Uber when it tried to recruit licensed operators to build its service within the letter of the law.

item.title: Iranian Protesters Ransack Saudi Embassy After Execution of Shiite Cleric
item.description: The execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, an outspoken campaigner for Shiite rights, is likely to exacerbate sectarian tensions across the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Shiites carrying a placard with an image of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr at a protest in Srinagar, in the disputed region of Kashmir, on Saturday.
